title: changes-north-berwicks-law-road-create-one-way-system
story: Pop-up bollards are being installed today on Law Road, from Kirk Ports to the junction with St Margaretrsquos Road.Temporary changes are being made throughout East Lothian as part of the Spaces for People programme, to allow more space for physical distancing.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoThat part of the road will become a one-way system ndash cars [will] travel south up towards the crossroads.ldquoThe footpath is very narrow on that stretch of road, making it dficult for people to physically distance."This will widen the footpath to create that safer space for people walking into town or from the town towards nursery or the schools.The change is likely to remain until the end of the year.

title: angelina-jolie-interviewed-schoolgirl-bbc-newsround
story: Sofia Roper, an S student at North Berwick High School, was offered the opportunity to talk with the actress, and her -year-old co-star Brooklynn Prince, by BBC Newsround.Sofia, , said: ldquoIt was fun but it was also scary. It was overwhelming.The budding journalist was hired by the BBC after the news channel approached the schoolrsquos humanities department, asking to interview students about their highs and lows of lockdown.The Newsround crew were so impressed by the video submitted by Sofia that they offered her the chance to become a reporter and interview, via an online video call, the stars of new film The One And Only Ivan.Sofia, of High Street, East Linton, told the Courier that she did some research before talking to the film star.She said: ldquoI chose to do some research because itrsquos good to have a personal aspect to your questions.ldquoI practised interviewing with Ali Plumb [BBC Radio  film reporter] and it was much easier, I didnrsquot feel nervous at all talking to him, but then when I talked to Angelina I was very nervous. And I donrsquot understand why!Sofia joined  professional journalists on video conferencing  Zoom, all waiting for their slot to interview the Hollywood stars.Student Sofia Roper waits on Zoom to interview Angelina JolieShe said: ldquoIt was hard to hide that I was so nervous and imagine that I was talking to a completely normal person.ldquoAngelina and Brooklynn were friendly but they made me feel very scared, just because they had this kind of presence you could tell they were more confident.But Sofia said the experience had also made her more confident and was one she would be happy to have again.She said: ldquoOne of my old teachers was saying that I was a lot more confident now than I was when she taught me.Sofiarsquos proud mum, Soledad Garcia Ferrari, said: ldquoIt was all very unexpected. Shersquos been brilliant. She had to do lots of videos in preparation, she had to watch the film and comment on it.ldquoIt was so funny seeing all the little windows on Zoom, of all the reporters from all over the world.ldquoAnd the interview was two hours later than planned, so she was sitting by her computer for two hours waiting.ldquoBut Angelina was very friendly.Georgina Brownlee, one of Sofiarsquos teachers in the humanities department, said: ldquoThe BBC got in touch during lockdown to ask for some clips of pupil lsquolockdown highs and lowsrsquo and a number of our junior pupils participated by entering a personal -second video clip, broadcast on Newsround during lockdown.ldquoFrom there, the BBC editor got in touch to ask Sofia to do a further interview, this time on the new Disney film The One and Only Ivan, starring Angelina Jolie.ldquoThe humanities faculty are delighted with Sofiarsquos impressive performance during her inaugural role as a BBC reporter she did a superb job interviewing a Hollywood megastar.ldquoSofia is a dedicated student and we will continue to facilitate the links and opportunities that have emerged from the BBC for all of our pupils.As for Sofiarsquos next journalist experience  The junior reporter said shersquod like to chat with a YouTuber.She said: ldquoI like YouTubers because they donrsquot have a script.ldquoYou donrsquot have to interview them to know what kind of person they are. Theyrsquore funny and entertaining.ldquoI like Georgia Productions ndash shersquos my favourite.The interview is at bbc newsround

title: coronavirus-maskne-seven-ways-look-skin-wearing-masks
story: However, people wearing face coverings every day have been noticing that they have started to break out in acne, rashes and skin irritations.Have you had more breakouts since you started wearing a mask We have spoken to Dermalogica skin care expert and beautician Ashley Richards to find out why this happens and how you can protect your skin.What is ldquomaskne Maskne occurs when sweat, oil and bacteria are trapped on your skin while wearing a mask, creating the perfect breeding ground for breakouts.What causes it Maskne is caused by friction, rubbing, and occlusion of the skin by outside forces.Wearing a mask can trap dirt, oil, swear and humidity around the skin.Friction and irritation from the mask pushes bacteria into the skin, which creates micro-tears, and allows the bacteria and dirt to enter the skin more easily.This will lead to blackheads and whiteheads along the bridge of your nose, cheeks and chin. Masks can trigger ious types of skin irritationsand redness .There isnrsquot a prevention for maskne, as we need to continue wearing our masks, but there are ways that you can help combat the issues.Skin Care routineIf you want to combat the impact of maskne then having a good skincare routine is essential.It is just as important to cleanse your skin before wearing a mask as it is to cleanse after wearing a mask.To help your skin heal, Ashley would recommend using a squalane or balm cleanser so help remove make-up, dirt and debris.However,you are experiencing chapped, irritated skin or suffer from sensitivity then a gel based cleanseradvised.Dermalogicarsquos UltraCalming Cleanser helps to calm and cool sensitised irritated skin.ExfoliatingExfoliating is key to clear clogged pores and remove dead skin cells which will help reduce the impact of maskne.There are thousands of dferent types of exfoliators available from chemical, physical and masks but it is always important to follow the recommended application and how often you should use the product.Over-exfoliating your skin can compromise your skins barrier , damage the skins capillaries and dehydrate the skin.Ingredients such as glycolic acid, lactic acid and salicylic acid are great exfoliating athelping fight breakouts.Spot treatmentsUsing targeted spot treatments with ingredients such as salicylic acid and benzoyl peroxide will help remove dead skin cells and decongest pores.Hyaluronic AcidsHyaluronic acid can hold , times its weight in water - so it is like a magnet for moisture.Using hyaluronic acid regularly will leave the skin feeling super-soft, radiant and reduce the appearance of fine lines and wrinkles.Hyaluronic acid has antibacterial properties meaning it will help soothe and protect chapped, irritated skin.FoundationsOpt for tinted moisturisers rather than a heavy foundation or go bare faced to help cause less clogging in your pores - but donrsquot forget your SPF!MoisturisersHeavier moisturisers will sit on the skin for longer due to the humidity of wearing the mask which can cause further clogging and irritation of the skin.However, donrsquot want to stop using a moisturiser all together as our skin still requires hydration and moisture.Instead try using a light and soothing moisturise such as Charlotte Tilburyrsquos Magic Cream light.Chapped SkinFor those suffering from chapped skin try using a physical barrier cream such as Dermalogicarsquos Barrier Repair.Barrier Repair shields against environmental pollution and helps forty sensitive skin with a damaged barrier.

title: housing-plan-musselburgh-poundland-poundstretcher-post-office-site
story: An outline plan has been drawn up for the land and building that houses Poundstretcher, Poundland and the Post Office, which is currently up for sale.Edinburgh-based Scarlett Land and Development is inviting offers for the ldquoprime location with ldquoconsiderable redevelopment potential on behalf of the owner, who has not been named.Situated on the corner of Dalrymple Loan and High Street, an outline plan for  residential properties plus two commercial units has been drawn up for the site, subject to planning permission.Scarlett Land and Development stated: ldquoThe site lies in the defined town centre, adjacent to the Musselburgh Conservation Area and in close proximity to listed buildings.ldquoPlanning permission will be required for any redevelopment proposal and, whilst not allocated for any specic use within the East Lothian Local Development Plan, it is likely that a mixed use development of ground floor commercial with residential use above will be acceptable, subject to a high-quality scheme respecting the setting of the listed buildings, the character and appearance of the adjacent conservation area and the scale of buildings in the surrounding area.Architects have drawn up an outline scheme comprising of  residential units plus two commercial units at ground level fronting High Street. The housing is listed as one, two and three-bedroom properties, plus two commercial units of  and  sq.m.A spokesperson for Poundland said: ldquoWe rent the store from the landlord and so the ownership is not really our concern. But we love being in Musselburgh and are proud to be part of the townrsquos retail community.A Post Office spokesperson said: ldquoThe premises where Musselburgh Post Office is based are up for sale. Poundstretcher is the company that operates this Post Office. We have not received any resignation at this stage, so it is business as usual at this Post Office.Poundstretcher had not responded at the time of going to press.Colin Beattie, Musselburgh MSP, said: ldquolsquoAny business being put up for sale comes at a cost to the community, as with the loss of a local business comes a loss of jobs and services to the area.ldquoWhile we come out of the Covid- pandemic, we need businesses as we start to re-energise our economy. Though we also need more houses to be built locally, I would hope that these are not replacing valuable businesses locally ndash a decision which is permanent and negatively affects the lives of anyone employed there.ldquoI hope that suitable thought goes into this proposal and that the iniduals that this would affect are given the utmost consideration.ldquoAs always, I hope that the highest attention is given to the views of those who live in the community, as their opinions are what really matter in planning decisions.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothian MP, said: ldquoDevelopment is needed but must be appropriate for a busy location and central site.Musselburgh Conservation Society said it would reserve its position until members saw what was being proposed.Musselburgh resident and Green campaigner Jason Rose, via social media, mooted the idea of the community owning the site and asked members of the public what they would like to see.One post stated: ldquoA proper covered market with independent fishmongers, grocers and butchers, plus other local producers and space for outdoor stalls too.ldquoWhat is needed is parking. No parking, limited shoppers, added a member of the public.Another said: ldquoSomething for the creative industry would be good. Small units at reasonable rents, photography studio with workshop space, sound recording studio, rehearsal spaces for bands musicians.One post added: ldquoCould be nice to have a proper supermarket right on High St again.ldquoMy granny was forever complaining that Tesco was too far and it is quite a walk.

title: iain-gray-msp-column-rediscover-solidarity-lockdown
story: However, recess never actually happened ndash Parliament has continued to meet throughout the summer to deal with Covid- and related issues.It is a moment to pause and reflect, though. Over the summer, we have seen lockdown partially eased but that is not proving easy.Cases are rising again. The Government has had to slow down its lsquoroute maprsquo to opening society up, and that has led to what seem like contradictions.Pubs and restaurants open, but gyms and swimming pools closed young adults wearing face coverings in supermarkets but not in schools a list of lsquoquarantinersquo countries which changes almost daily.If this is the lsquonew normalrsquo, then in some ways it is proving harder than everyone being locked down. We all applauded the NHS as it coped so well with the virus peak, but many constituents are becoming frustrated at how long it is taking to open up for their routine treatments or operations.Only weeks ago we were hailing Scotland as doing so much better than England.It turns out the pandemic numbers were just being counted dferently, and local lockdowns around Manchester were followed by Annan and Aberdeen. Scottish people have proven just as likely to flock to the beach or ill-advised house parties as anyone .Everyonersquos patience is being tested now. We can do this, though. Remember the community spirit which saw resilience groups form in all of our towns and villages  Remember clapping for the NHS and social care workers  Remember looking out for vulnerable neighbours and friends  It is time to rediscover that solidarity and keep on looking out for, and looking after, each other.

title: coronavirus-scotland-book-covid-test-testing-centres
story: The First Minister suggests some Scots have had trouble trying to book coronavirus tests over the weekend due to a "major spike" in demand, which resulted in technical issues.Butyou are experiencing symptoms, how do you get a test  Heres everything you need to know.If you think you are experiencing symptoms of coronavirus, you should take a test. A test should be taken within the first three days of showing symptoms, but testing is effective until day five.You wonrsquot normally be tested after day  unless itrsquos for a specic reason. This will be agreed on a case-by-case basis.Anyone with symptoms of coronavirus should be tested. You can book a test for either yourself,someone you care for ora child in your care.Key workers, and anyone in their household with symptoms, can access testing through their employer in the first instance and will be given priority.For more information on key worker priority, visit NHS Inform.Currently, there are testing sites at Glasgow, Edinburgh, Aberdeen and Prestwick airports, and in Perth and Inverness at the University of the Highlands and Islands campuses.There are also home testing kits available, which are delivered and collected by Amazon and Royal Mail. You can order one here.There are several ways to get tested for Covid- in Scotland.You can have a home testing kit delivered to your home, or attend one of the testing sites.To book a test, you are asked to complete a self-help guide, which can be found online, to checkyou are eligible. If you cant access the form online, you can callthe coronavirus helpline on   .The coronavirus tests involves taking a swab of the inside of your nose and the back of your throat. This is done using a long cotton bud.According to NHS Inform, results are issued to whoever booked the test and are fed back into public health records.They are sent by text to your mobile phone and should be with you within  hours.

title: hollies-day-centre-musselburgh-reopen-monday
story: Liz Shannon, manager, said the reopening of the High Street facility, which offers activities for older people as well as a public cafe, would be ldquoin a limited capacity to allow for social distancing.The public cafe and hairdresser will be back in business on Monday, with hopes that other activities, such as the lunch club, might start again next month.Ms Shannon said: ldquoMajor work has been carried out over the lockdown period, including a deep clean of the building.ldquoWe are sorry but, due to the current pandemic, a number of changes have had to be put in place for customersrsquo and staff safety, and to comply with Government health and safety guidelines. As before, we are a cash-only facility.The cafe will reopen in the hall am-pm, Monday to Wednesday.Ms Shannon said: ldquoWe will see how it will work and,it works well, we can extend our days back to five.ldquoThere will be a limited number of customers able to attend, around , and the time in the cafe limited to  minutes per person. Entry will be by the black gate from High Street into the hall. A track and trace system will be in place and customers will be required to leave their name and contact telephone number, have their hands sanitised and wear a face covering until seated. All must comply with these conditions or entry will be prohibited. A limited menu will be provided at this stage.The hairdresser at the day centre will also reopen by appointment, following the same days, times and entry system.Ms Shannon said: ldquoCustomers for the hairdresser will have to keep a mask on at all times and use the stair lt to the first floor. They will be required to bring their own refreshments as no tea or coffee will be provided.She stressed both cafe and hairdresser customers would leave from the front door of the building.Ms Shannon paid tribute to Musselburgh-based RR Roofing  Building Ltd, which came to the rescue last week to carry out repairs on a leaky roof at the centre which, it had been feared, could have been a major setback to the reopening.

title: 60-events-offer-east-lothian-online-heritage-festival
story: East Lothian Online Heritage Festival boasts events ranging from virtual guided tours and presentations to films and workshops.The festival, on until September , is running in place of the traditional Archaeology and Local History Fortnight, which has been postponed.Events include The Big Glassworks Dig at Port Seton on September  and . Digs will be broadcast live so everyone can follow any discoveries from the old glassworks as they are uncovered.Battlefield events commemorating the Battles of Dunbar, Pinkie Cleugh and Prestonpans, including live footage from the commemoration ceremonies, will take place, as well as online exhibitions and films related to the Year of Coast and Waters, using historic images and oral histories from the archives.Councillor Norman Hampshire, cabinet spokesman for the environment, said: ldquoIrsquom delighted our archaeology service has developed this alternative way of celebrating East Lothianrsquos rich heritage and history.ldquoWith a vast array of historic buildings and sites to explore virtually through more than  events, Irsquod encourage people to participate.On Saturday, events include the chance to join the Salt of the Earth project for a day of celebration of the heritage of the Prestonpans, Cockenzie and Port Seton, Longniddry and Gosford areas.There is the chance to take a virtual walk around Tranentrsquos historic burgh boundary and a guided heritage walk over, under and around seven bridges over the Esk in Musselburgh.Also on Saturday, Graeme Cavers, from AOC Archaeology, will give a presentation about how LiDAR was used to map the archaeology of the Lammermuirs. A traditional skills festival looking at everything from stone carving and pottery to herb foraging and plaster casting takes place.A short film based on interviews with fishermen from Cockenzie and Port Seton will be shown, while there is also a chance to find out how to build your own lsquoTrace Italiennersquo fort.On Sunday, Nicola Wright will tell stories inspired by coast, water and archaeology, while a childrenrsquos workshop takes place in Amisfield Walled Garden, near Haddington. Liz Curtis shares stories behind the place names of East Lothian and there is a presentation about John Muirrsquos home in Dunbar.Monday starts with a look at the history of Dunbar, which is marking  years since the town was granted its charter.Gullane and Dirleton History Society hosts a virtual guided walk of the Gullane end of the old branch railway line.The following day, a film looking at the Cousland Smiddy is shown, while there is a slideshow of some of the historic re-enactment events that Catching the Past has been involved in.Historian David Affleck explores the history of Whittingehame Estate, while Kate Campbell has written a collection of poetry inspired by the area around Whiteadder Reservoir.On Wednesday, a short slideshow looks at the history of county ports and harbours and Courier columnist Tim Porteus tells three East Lothian tales.For more information, go to johngraycentre.org

title: first-full-east-lothian-council-meeting-since-lockdown-sees-local-heroes-praised
story: A momentrsquos silence was held for those people who died from Covid- and their families, as councillors paid tribute to the community efforts which had come to the fore during the crisis.Councillor Fiona Dugdale summed up the praise from elected members during the virtual meeting, held online, by saying: ldquoI do not think there are enough words to thank our staff and the amazing army of volunteers who stepped up in the midst of a national health crisis not knowing how it would affect or its impact on their own families.ldquoThe depth of gratitude is immense to all our staff and all our volunteers across the county,ldquoThey are all our local heroes at the heart of our communities.And Provost John McMillan told the committee: ldquoA hero is an ordinary person who does extraordinary things and all those ordinary people who stepped up did extraordinary things.The council meeting heard that a snapshot of services provided by the council and its partners the week before community resilience teams stood down showed , people who were shielding were in contact with support teams and , free school meals and lunch packs were delivered to children.The six childrenrsquos hubs which provided care for the families of key workers and vulnerable children at its peak in June saw  young people attend and  teaching staff working in them.Councillor Willie Innes, council leader, said: ldquoRight across the county, people have been magnicent.ldquoI am proud of our council staff, who have worked above and beyond to ensure the safety and wellbeing of communities.And Councillor Jim Goodfellow, spokesperson for community wellbeing, said: ldquoThe magnicent numbers of volunteers who have come forward has demonstrated what this county is all about.Councillor Fiona OrsquoDonnell also added her thanks to staff and volunteers, pointing to work in her Preston SetonGosford ward, from community councils to third sector and volunteers.And fellow ward councillor Lachlan Bruce said that too many people to name had made remarkable efforts to support the communities.Mr Bruce said: ldquoWe are incredibly lucky in this county and it has highlighted how great this county is, with communities coming together, all doing amazing work.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, education spokesperson, passed on her thanks to parents and carers for their work.And Councillor Craig Hoy also paid tribute to shop workers who kept services open.He said: ldquoLocal shops, petrol stations and small businesses, as well as large supermarkets and small stores, all stayed open to support their communities throughout and should be thanked.Councillor Stuart Currie called for a moment of silence to be held, saying: ldquoIt is right to remember the people who are not going to see the other side of this pandemic and their families.The council closed the meeting with a moment of silent reflection in tribute.

title: haddington-residents-yard-sale-helps-support-community-kitchen
story: Residents of Burnside, Clerkington Road and Fairway came together to do their bit for Our Community Kitchen.The lsquoyard salersquo collected pound for the group, which meets in Haddington Bowling Club.Elaine Gale, who founded Our Community Kitchen, was delighted with the success of the event at the beginning of the month.She said: ldquoIt is just so lovely.ldquo[Support from the community] has been enormous really and the amount and sheer scale of support we have had locally for what we are doing is absolutely incredible.The money raised will go towards the general running costs of the group, which, pre-coronavirus, was serving up lunches to people who were suffering from isolation in the bowling club.However, with social gatherings ruled out, the group decided to continue preparing meals but instead take them to peoplersquos homes.Meals such as chicken and leek pie and stovies have been delivered to homes throughout Haddington during the lockdown period.That will be scaled back slightly as restrictions are eased but Elaine said they were still delivering more than  meals a week to people in need.Volunteers have also been taking the time to phone vulnerable members of the community to check they are alright.The scheme will continue and Elaine said: ldquoAs a charity, we are committed to looking after the community.ldquoThat is part of what we will be doing going forward thatrsquos not going to stop.ldquoWe recognise people will still need us.

title: lyn-jardine-hopes-snps-east-lothian-candidate-scottish-parliament-election-2021
story: Lyn Jardine, a former chair of Womenrsquos Aid East and Midlothian, has joined Dunbar and East Linton Councillor Paul McLennan, and Iain Whyte, office manager for Paul Wheelhouse, South of Scotland MSP and energy minister, in seeking to be the partyrsquos candidate for East Lothian in .The party is expected to announce its candidate in late October, with hopefuls vetted before local members are asked to choose their preferred person.Mrs Jardine said: ldquoIn order to deliver both independence and the support we deserve, East Lothian needs an MSP who exhibits the competence and determination to bring about the changes necessary.ldquoIrsquove shown that competence ndash serving our communities in both professional and voluntary capacity ndash and Irsquom determined to keep doing so as your MSP.ldquoIrsquove worked all my le in housing, health and social care, across public and third sectors, as well as self-employed.ldquoI served several years as chair of Womenrsquos Aid East and Midlothian and on both the child and adult protection committees across both local authorities.A new MSP for East Lothian will be selected when the elections take place in May.Iain Grayhas held the seat since  but is not seeking re-election.Labour are yet to announce their candidate, with Councillor Craig Hoy, who represents the Haddington and Lammermuir ward on East Lothian Council, already named as the Conservativesrsquo candidate.No other candidate has yet been announced.Mrs Jardine, who lives in Whittingehame, felt the SNP was ldquoin a good place across the county.The elected organiser for East Lothian SNP, who would be the partyrsquos first woman candidate for East Lothian for the Scottish Parliament, said: ldquoI worked with the campaign team supporting the successful European and Westminster election campaigns, and I have no doubt that whoever is selected, our members will put the same passion into campaigning for a better deal for East Lothian and a fairer, more equal Scotland.

title: east-lothian-council-astro-turf-ban
story: The schoolrsquos popular astroturf pitch ndash used primarily for hockey but also other activities ndash proved too big a draw for youngsters as classes ed full-time and it was closed to students at breaks and lunchtime.Parents urged the school to reconsider the decision after youngsters came home claiming they had been told the risk of them touching goal posts ndash and potentially creating a higher risk of spreading Covid- ndash was too great.And the school said that it would introduce a system which would allow children access to the pitch one day a week on a year by year basis.As classes ed in full last Monday, it is understood staff became concerned at the number of students gathering together on the astroturf pitch from dferent years.However, the decision to ban children from the pitch left some parents bemused.One mum took to social media, saying: ldquoSurely the kids can touch door frames and bins and walls in all the other outdoor areas ndash why are the goal posts so scary Another added: ldquoI understand they are under pressure and trying to keep kids and adults safe but surely this isnrsquot necessary One mum received a reply from the schoolrsquos PE department pledging to look into a way more supervision could be given to the pitch to allow youngsters to use it in a ldquosafe and sensible manner.Each year group has now been allowed to use the astroturf one day a week.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoThe astroturf is a popular facility at North Berwick High School.ldquoIn line with official guidance, the school is discouraging large groups from congregating and the space was being used by a number of dferent year groups at the same time.ldquoIt was closed to young people for two days to allow the staff team to put in place a schedule that will allow each year group to use it one day a week with staff supervision and cleaning in place.ldquoThis is especially important as it is also used for PE. North Berwick High School, like all our schools, is working hard to understand and apply guidance on theto our buildings.ldquoWhere we can identy better ways of working we are doing so. This is one example.

title: preston-lodge-high-school-headteacher-gavin-clark-apologises-pupils-soaked
story: Initial guidelines introduced by the school meant pupils were told to go outside at lunchtime and during breaks despite the downpours, with claims they were only allowed inside to use the toilets. Some pupils said they ed home wearing jackets and hoodies still soaked from being out in the rain earlier in the day.Afterwards, Mr Clark sent a letter to families, telling them: ldquoWe very much regret the fact that many of our students got wet at break, lunch and or in PE lessons on Monday and we have worked hard over the last  hours to reassure a number of parents carers who raised understandable concerns.ldquoWe were perhaps working too hard to meet national guidance, and on this occasion our desire to maximise student time outside and prevent large gatherings of students indoors, as per Government advice, negatively impacted on student wellbeing.And in the schoolrsquos PLus newsletter, he said: ldquoWe have had a really good week at Preston Lodge, after a dficult Monday. Heavy rain, combined with a challenging set of Government guidelines, led to many students getting wet on that day, but I am glad to say that today our new approach to indoor breaks worked well and, other than those who chose to go outside, everyone stayed dry!An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoAll schools are working hard to implement guidance to provide a safeto buildings. In particular, secondary schools have to minimise large gatherings within indoor spaces and encourage small groups with physical distancing outwith.ldquoOur schools have been clear to all parents that children and young people should come to school dressed for the weather.ldquoTheto school this year has been challenging and we, and our schools, are working hard to understand and apply guidance. Where we can identy better ways of working we are doing so. The headteacherrsquos letter was part of this process.

title: resilient-musselburgh-stands-months-helping-community
story: The team has been running a local emergency service since the last week in March, initially from a base at Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School before moving to Musselburgh East Community Learning Centre on Haddington Road.The efforts, which attracted about  local volunteers, were coordinated by Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council, Musselburgh Area Partnership and East Lothian Council workers.Help from the community council was given by chairperson Irene Tait, vice-chairperson Bernard Harkins and secretary Margaret Stewart.Also giving support were area partnership chairman Iain Clark and manager Stuart Baxter, as well as Jane Cummings, Pamela Martin, Donna Doherty and Trisha McGeachy from East Lothian Council.With help from the volunteers, aid was delivered to vulnerable people in the community during the Covid- crisis.Mrs Tait said: ldquoWith the help of volunteers, we have delivered hundreds of hot meals, soup and sandwiches, food parcels, hygiene products, prescriptions, activity packs for children and adults, newspapers, garden tools and much more. None of this would have been possible without our wonderful volunteers, who went above and beyond many times, so a huge thank you to them.ldquoWe would also like to thank Tesco, Hickory, Mercat Bar  Grill at Whitecraig, Pinkie Farm Shop and many of the local shops that donated to us during this time.ldquoThanks also to local organisations for their donations and help given to Resilient Musselburgh.ldquoLastly, our thanks go out to our community for continuing to do the right thing.

title: coronavirus-nearly-100-pupils-staff-self-isolating-across-lothians
story: Eighty-eight pupils and eight members of staff who have been in close and sustained contact with the pupils who tested positive have been told to self-isolate for  days as a precautionary measure.Currently, there is no evidence of transmission within the schools themselves.On Wednesday, East Lothian Council said it was ldquoa worrying time for families after it was confirmed a pupil had tested positive.Details of the age of the pupil or what class they are in at the Prestonpans primary school have not been released.A spokesman for the local authority said: ldquoThatrsquos why we are working with NHS Lothianrsquos health protection team and will continue to closely monitor the situation and follow all national guidance and the health advice provided.ldquoChildren who have been in direct contact with the confirmed case have been contacted and will be staying at home for  days.ldquoThe school remains open, in line with expert public health advice."The Health Protection Team in NHS Lothian has worked with single cases in six schools across Lothianrsquos four separate local authority areas to contact trace and assess the safety measures in place, such as social distancing and enhanced cleaning.Preston Tower is the only school in East Lothian to have recorded a positive test.All of the schools in East Lothian, Edinburgh, Midlothian and West Lothian remain open following the inidual cases and parents have been told that their child should still attend, unless instructed otherwise.Professor Alison McCallum, director of public health and health policy, said: ldquoWe have been made aware of a number of pupils who have tested positive for Covid- over the course of this week.ldquoWe know this is a worrying time for them and their families, but indeed also for other people in the local school community.ldquoOur teams are working with schools to ensure that all of the necessary infection control measures are in place to protect other young people and their families.ldquoAll of the schools remain open and parents should continue to send their children to school.

title: east-lothian-pupils-asked-bring-face-masks-school-monday
story: Lesley Brown, the councilrsquos head of education and childrenrsquos services, said in the letter: ldquoAs yoursquoll be aware, the Scottish Government has announced that, from August , face coverings should be worn by young people attending secondary schools when they are moving around the school in corridors and confined communal areaswhere physical distancing is particularly dficult to maintain.ldquoThis new advice comes from the World Health Organisationand is based on evidence that transmission risks amongst teenagers are the same as amongst adults.ldquoThese measures will ensure we are up-to-date with the latest advice about how to keep our schools open and safe.ldquoBy following these new guidelines, you and your child will be supporting our schools to ensure health and safety remains a key priority, and that all staff and pupils can be confident they are in a safe environment.ldquoThis means that, from Monday, you should provide your child with a face covering to wear at school in these circumstances.Students may also wear face coverings in classrooms, though this is not compulsory.Face coverings must be worn by adults in classrooms where they cannot keep a two-metre distance and are interacting face-to-face with other adults and or children and young people for  minutes or more.Those who have a health condition or disability which affects their ability to wear a face covering hygienically or safely are exempt from the ruling.Schools will also continue to reinforce the importance of high standards of cleaning, personal hand and respiratory hygiene, and physical distancing.

title: new-bbc-documentary-series-jamie-genevieve-great-indoors-air-week
story: The make-up artist, who is a worldwide star on YouTube and Instagram, will star in the three-part series Jamie Genevieve: Great Indoors on BBC Scotland onThursday at . pm.It comes after the success of her first documentary for the networks BBC Scotland channel Jamie Genevieve #Unfiltered.The former Cathkin High School pupil started out working in make-up counters in Debenhams in Glasgow.Now she is known for her how to make-up demonstrations on YouTube.The new mini-series focuses on how Jamie and husband Jack is coping in the middle of the coronavirus pandemic from trying her hand at hairdressing to baking.

title: eight-best-cars-family-staycation
story: . Audi AIf youre looking for a big, premium estate car for family duties, there are fewer better than the latest generation Audi A. Its available as both a saloon and estate, and either way has a massive cabin and a big boot.One of the real standout points is the cabin quality, with sleek touchscreens on the dashboard that really take the premium feel up a notch making long journeys all the more pleasant.. Land Rover DefenderWhile the old Defender was focused on being a utilitarian off-road machine, the new one aims to bring those abilities with some on-road sensibilities and luxuries. Land Rover has succeeded, bringing a x thats comfortable to drive at motorway speeds and has plenty of space inside for adults, kids, and all their things.Whats more,youre going off the beaten track at your destination, nothing will be better equipped to get you there.. Peugeot  SWPeugeot has been knocking rivals out of the park recently when it comes to good-looking, practical and great-to-drive cars ndash and the  SW is the best combination of all these things. Its perfect for people who dont want the predictable German models because this Peugeot is full of character.Its not the most exciting car to drive, and the quirky interior can be a little unintuitive to use, but for family duties, its perfect and will swallow miles with ease.. Seat TarracoEvery car manufacturer builds SUVs these days, and one of the best value is the Seat Tarraco. Not only is it well-priced, but it also has fantastic build quality, smart looks and loads of space ndash with seating for seven, making it perfect for larger families.Because its part of the Volkswagen Group, the Tarraco has access to plenty of efficient engines, so whatever your driving style theres an option for you. The .-litre diesels will be best for long-distance staycation road trips.. Volkswagen Tiguan AllspaceThe VW Tiguan is a good-sized SUV, butsize really matters, its the Tiguan Allspace you want. The clues in the name, but this model extends the SUV shape so theres more luggage space and room for two more seats. Its also essentially a Seat Tarraco underneath.The downside is that its not cheap, because its only available in three high-spec trims. However, the upside is that its incredibly well-equipped.. Mazda  TourerAnother car manufacturer providing fun, characterful alternatives to the typical German models, Mazdas  Tourer is a handsome and practical estate thats well worth your attention. The Japanese firm is one of the brands that really nails a premium feel to its interiors too, without the premium price.Dont be put off by the large engines either, because the  s impressive fuel economy, with Mazda focusing on refining traditional engines rather than fully pursuing electrication.. BMW  Series TouringThe go-to name in the executive car segment, the BMW  Series has long been the standard-bearer for families who want badge appeal, high-quality interiors and a decent driving experience.The latest models are packed full of technology, and while they arent as fun to drive as the older versions, theyre perfect for long-distance motoring.. Dacia DusterWhile most of the cars on this list have some element of premium appeal, the Dacia Duster sits at the opposite end of the market, where its low price aims to appeal to those with a tighter budget. However, while the entry-level models dont have much kit and a cheap-feeling interior, spend a little more and you get decent equipment and a comfortable interior for the price of a second hand car.

title: Opinion  Rosemary Goring  Why we are all going mad for the joys of gardening
story: In recent months, it seems our village has been bang on trend as ever. Across the UK, as headlines foretold the devastation lockdown would wreak on this seasonal trade ndash footage of acres of wilting plants was grim ndash cannier businesses immediately shted to online and telephone orders. And, as recent figures show, people responded enthusiastically. During that period, Britons spent around pound. billion on garden plants, materials and tools. Contrary to the stereotypical picture of a Mr McGregor retiree, footering around in his potting shed, it was millennials who spent most. Their investment was double that of the rest of us, with the - age group spending an average pound per person, compared with pound among others.Some of that might be explained by the urgent need for equipment to turn a rectangle of grass into a more imaginative space for all the family to enjoy. Irsquom long past their age but still so new to gardening that I recall those early months as a ceaseless outlay on shears, secateurs, spades, forks, trowels, rakes, sieves... I could go on. Hence the need for a shed, which was soon festooned with tools dangling from hooks, propped against walls and stacked on shelves. Think of an Italian deli, with hams and salamis overhead, and floor to ceiling storage. Replace the delicious aroma of cheeses, coffee beans and truffles with potting compost, muddied buckets and oil to keep blades moving, and you get the picture.There are professional horticulturalists where I live who are well under , but thatrsquos probably not surprising. Those who choose to live in the country are already keen on the outdoors, whatever their vintage. Yet there is something of a renaissance occurring in this generation, as interest in their own plot is sparked into le, whether itrsquos an allotment, balcony, or back yard.In response to what you might call a growing trend, Alan Titchmarsh has said that he hopes more young folk will be encouraged to pick up their trowels and dig up drives, to help protect the planet. ldquoItrsquos not just about going on marches, he says. ldquoBeing practical is a hugely underrated resource and skill.Those who have unexpectedly found themselves with time to devote to their patch have probably realised how enjoyable it is too. Being in the fresh air, surrounded by birds, and perhaps with children larking around, has shown how much pleasure can be had in maintaining your part of the world. At this stage of le, competition for peoplersquos spare time is usually ferocious, with the demands of socialising, keeping fit and raising a family. In the past, unless you were actively emulating the Good Le, choosing to spend the weekend planting drills of potatoes or deadheading roses was borderline eccentric.Being forced to spend so much time at home has clearly made people reassess their outdoor space, and consider its potential. Making their plot child-friendly has been a priority for some. But for those who dread the thought of a football landing on tender seedlings and new blooms, there should be no conflict between serious cultivation and youngsters ndash quite the opposite. The earlier children encounter flowers and trees and the wildle they attract, the better for all our futures. And the sooner they recognise the need to treat living things with respect ndash although some trampling and breakage is almost inevitable ndash the more they will understand not just how nature works, but the ways in which we can support it.Irsquove lost count of the number of people who have said how much they have relished this aspect of lockdown. Having nowhere  to go has allowed them to concentrate on matters horticultural, and take time to make decisions or try experiments they otherwise could not have attempted. Having many more unfilled free hours has its upsides, as one neighbour has discovered. When the pandemic took hold she turned her greenhouse into a hotbed of tomatoes and her flowerbeds into a lettuce patchwork, and has been feasting on salads all summer. As have her friends.Inevitably, once the world opens up again, some recent converts will lose interest and the weeds will take revenge. Yet I have no doubt that many will already be hooked. The secret that no gardener ever mentions is that it is addictive. Each tiny success gives confidence to try something more adventurous. Mistakes are inevitable, but so are accidental triumphs. The thrill of discovering strawberries or nasturtiums thriving where before was a bed of nettles, is inspiring. The sight of bees and birds hovering for nectar, seeds and grubs is like preparing a banquet and watching as guests pile their plates high. To be honest, environmental reasons for sustainable, eco-friendly gardening are all but forgotten in the joy it brings. The reason why benches in most well-tended grounds go largely unused is because therersquos always something clamouring for attention. To sit sipping a GT while an unpruned shrub stares at you reproachfully, or a juicy stick of rhubarb cries out to be picked, is almost impossible.In my own limited experience, trying to keep on top of it all ndash and never coming remotely close ndash is part of what it is about. An expert recently told me that a garden will take all the time you give it, and then some. Yet the depths of winter is the time to put your feet up . The rest of the year is for helping the green things around you put down sturdy roots. As millennials can confirm, it has a very stabilising, calming effect on us too.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: coronavirus-surge-demand-testing-schools-returned-foreseen
story: Not because it necessarily poses a major public health risk, but because the start of any new school term triggers a spike in cold and flu-like viruses that could easily be mistaken for Covid-, thus precipitating exactly the surge in demand for testing that has occurred in recent weeks.A glance at the latest statistics for Scotland shows that during the seven days to August  - when schools began re-opening - a total of , people in Scotland were newly tested for the virus. This resulted in  new cases being detected - a positivity rate of . per cent.In the seven days to August , the number of people being tested had risen sharply to ,, with  new cases identied - a .% positivity rate.Many of these iniduals will have been tested more than once across the NHS and community sites we are now performing more than , Covid antigen tests per week - the highest turnover since the pandemic began.: Scotland to roll out -minute Covid testsDespite this sudden upswing in demand - and bearing in mind that the vast majority of testing is carried out on iniduals with possible Covid symptoms - % of those tested are still coming back negative for the Sars-CoV- virus.While some of these may be  negatives, it is also a strong indicator of just how many non-Covid viral infections are circulating in the community causing coughs and fevers.Young children have also long been known to be lsquosuperspreadersrsquo of colds and flu - yet the same does not appear to be true for the newest strain of coronavirus behind the pandemic.Emerging evidence suggests that older children aged  and over can infect others with Covid in much the same way as adults, however, leading the World Health Organisation to update its guidance to advise that teenagers should wear facemasks in certain circumstances.There is less concern about the danger of the virus to children and adolescents per se. The evidence is overwhelming that the age group is at extremely low risk of serious illness or complications.The real alarm surrounds their potential to pass the infection on to adults on campus, or to bring it home to family members who may be a greater risk.Yet even this is unclear.: Fresh call to lt cap on medical school intake for A Public Health England study published on Sunday analysed outbreaks linked to primary and pre-school children during June.Of the million or so children attending,  children and  members of staff were infected in  separate outbreaks - but PHE said most had probably been caused by staff members infecting other staff members, with only two instances apparently linked to pupild infecting other pupils.However, a study by French epidemiologist Arnaud Fontanet at a school in France found that although younger age groups do not "transmit to the same extent", "teenagers are just as contagious as adults".Dr Simon Clarke, associate professor of cellular microbiology at the University of Reading, told the Independent that it was best to ldquoerr on the side of caution when discussing whether the coronavirus can be transmitted to adults by children.ldquoTherersquos not a mountain of evidence on both sides," he said. "The fact is we know very little about this, precious little.The bottom line, however, is that our testing capacity has not kept pace with the predictable surge in demand caused by schools reopening.The same pattern is occurring in countries such as South Korea, where schools in Seoul were forced to close and revert back to distance learning this week after the th consecutive day of triple-digit daily increases in coronavirus cases. At least  students and teachers have tested positive over the past two weeks in the Seoul city region.Germany too was forced to completely or partially close some of its schools or quarantine pupils and teachers within days of the new term two weeks ago. In Berlin,  schools have been affected by Covid- cases.The messaging in Scotland was clear: schools could only open safely as long as anyone with possible symptoms stayed home and got tested straightaway.: Contact tracing will only prevent outbreakstesting carried out within  hours of symptomsModelling by academics from University College London and the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine predicted that reopening of schools in England in September could lead to a second, bigger wave of coronavirus by December unless a "comprehensive test, trace and isolate strategy" was in place. This took into account other factors - such as parents being freed up toto offices- but it illustrates the importance of sufficient and rapid testing capacity.The fact that our testing capacity has been overwhelmed so quickly - evensome of it is confusion among people told to self-isolate wrongly seeking tests - is far from ideal.On the plus side, the test results we do have so far indicate that Covid is only behind around one in every  cases of flu-like illness.

title: TV REVIEW   Location  Location  Location  20 Years and Counting  Has it been a show too long
story: Channel  All  ***I KNOW what you are thinking. Can I really have spent  years of my le watching two posh sorts show punters round mid-priced houses with scope for an extension round the back ldquoHave we changed in  years  Phil Spencer asked his oppo, Kirstie Allsopp, at the start of this look back in languor show featuring the best bits of the Channel  property programme.ldquoHave you looked at your hair  shrieked Kirstie with all the JCB-in-a-china-shop delicacy for which she is known.Britainrsquos second most famous couple who are not a couplereally have been at this lark for a long time. Sometimes they have even found properties people go on to buy. Mostly, though, each episode is a lesson in home-hunting reality: what the buyer can afford versus what they want. Everything is a compromise, except for the cardinal rule set out in the title.On that, Kirstie had some shock news. ldquoI bought in the wrong area, she told Phil as they reminisced about their first flats . Kirstiersquos mum thought the neighbourhood was safe, but the transport links were rubbish and it was a long way from her friends. So you see, Kirstie has been there, done that, and got the corns from a twice daily slog to and from a distant Tube station to show for it.: Kirsties Keep Crafting review The pair raced through house hunts down the years, starting with their first, a search for a one bed flat in central-ish London. Kate, the buyer, had pound, to spend. Today that would probably get you a part-share in a parking space.A laddish Phil and a foxy Kirstie, all knee high boots, swinging hair and shades, strode the London streets like Julie Burchill and Tony Parsons. Two hip young gunslingers taking on the world. Her voice was softer, her manner less confident. Phil hasnrsquot changed a bit, apart from the receding forehead.The essential building blocks of the show have stayed the same, too. ldquoWe headed to a quiet bar to think things through, said Phil in that first show. Cue the call to estate agents to put in a cheeky offer well under the asking price. Then the tense wait.Before getting to that point there were tours round houses, Kirstie being up front and pushy, Phil adopting a more softly-softly approach. Kirstie hated it when Phil said, as he did often, ldquoItrsquos up to them. Kirstie wanted to give buyers the stats on the best time to start a family so they would stop dithering about the number of bedrooms needed.We did not learn much that was new as Ben and Laura, Jess and Sam, and Michelle and Philip, followed the original Kate into the snakes and ladders game that is buying a house. But then after  years we have probably taken in Kirstie and Philrsquos advice by osmosis. Who does not know by now to look beyond the dreaded woodchip, or the value of knocking through : Which house was crowned Scotlands Home of the Year What we did leave with was a sense that Kirstie and Pip, as she calls him, have done well out of Location, Location, Location. Through dedication, dedication, dedication they have transformed a modest idea for a property show into a successful double decade career with spin-offs including Love it or List It. Thatrsquos pretty good going in TV today.Itrsquos all about chemistry, too, with the pairrsquos genial brother and sister best pals bickering making whatever time they have on screen fly by.Herersquos to the next  years. Who knows, by then the location in question might be Mars.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: letters-figures-prove-union-doesnt-work-scotland
story: Although Scotland is the best-performing area of the UK outside London and the south-east, the vast inequalities in regional performance in the UK are the greatest in Europe and raises questions about the suitability of the current economic and political models.Almost % of the total GERS deficitis interest levied for the UKrsquos national debt, which, under international law, Scotland is not liable for post-independence. In addition, pound.bn is removed from Scotlands accounts for UK defence , plus pound.bn for other UK services home and abroad, all of which a Scottish government with dferent priorities could reduce.Many small European countries have matched the UKrsquos Covid financial response and last year Norwayrsquos government raised almost pound billion from oil and gas revenues compared to the pound million attributed to Scotland, which is a lasting testament to Westminsterrsquos mismanagement and over-generous tax allowances.Unless we take the opportunity to change things with self-government, Scotlandrsquos fiscal position will only get worse after Brexit as the UK, despite consistently failing to balance its books, faces a decade of austerity.Mary Thomas, Edinburgh EH.IT would appear that Jill Stephensonis content to sponge off the taxpayers of the southeast of England. What a shameful position for anyone to take, either in a personal capacity or as a Scot.Scotlands economy has suffered a succession of catastrophic impacts at the hands of a succession of right-wing ideologically-driven governments, starting with Margaret Thatchers scrapping of Scotlands industrial capacity in the s, through the financial disaster of  and culminating with Brexit in . The fact that oil from Scotlands territory subsidised the de-industrialisation of the s and then supported the expansion of the City of Londons financial sector only underlines the irony of the position held by Ms Stephenson.Scotland will have the freedom to grow its economy only when it is free of interference by Westminster. The next catastrophe, of course, is going to be Brexit. Scotlands population has expanded steadily since ,, but that growth will stall as soon as Westminster is able to deny the immigration we need here. Scotlands GDP is considerably smaller than near neighbours with similar populations such as Norway, Denmark, Ireland and Finland, the reason for that is that these small independent countries can tailor their economies to their needs, not the needs of the city of London and the South East of England.Scotland doesnt need nuclear submarines, aircraft carriersor global military reach, all of which cost a lot more than the pound. billion that Ms Stephenson claims, but we do need infrastructure, health care, education and above all people to grow our economy.The GERS figures may seem to be a godsend to people who think like Ms Stephenson, but all they really do is underline the structural failures and weakness of the United Kingdoms economy.John Jamieson, Ayr.IT is sad to say that some who would refer to themselves as Scots appear proud of the fact that under the current constitutional arrangements Scotland seems, at least on a superficial level, to be "subsidised" by the rest of the UK. Of course not only is this assessment distorted because Wales, Northern Ireland and the North of England are apparently more heavily dependent on the largesse of Londoners, but because only tax revenues directly attributable to Scotland are included in Scottish revenues raised while non-directly attributable expenditures, such as defence, are pro-rated by Westminster.Of course the deliberately conjured smoke and mirrors hide the slanted workings of the UK economy which leverages resources from outside of the south-east of England to maximise the financial growth of London. Scotland was effectively in surplus for most of the last four decades but not only was no oil wealth fund created for the benefit of future generations, Scotland did not even obtain close to a population proportion of the massive infrastructure spending in and around London, an economically debilitating relative predicament which is set to continue for the foreseeable future . The people of Scotland are just as capable as those of our southern neighbour, but we can only prosper in accordance with our collective talents when we can invest all our resources in our own country.Stan Grodynski, Longniddry.THE annual furore over the GERS figures is now in predictable full swing. No one has ever seriously uttered the popular grievance mantra of "too poor, too smallrsquo with regards to Scotland.But this isnrsquot  any more. Oil prices have plummeted. Covid- is still playing out, in ways that cant be predicted. The global economy is reeling and climate instability is increasing.How much would an independent Scotland borrow, how would the deficit be dealt withincreased taxes or a reduction in services, or both. Or neither  How would Scotland be a competitive place for business The SNP needs to start tackling the "known unknowns and "unknown unknowns" of Scottish independence with a rigorous hard factual honesty that it has yet to muster, lest we all vote for a st century version of the Darien Scheme at some point in the future.Surely the people of Scotland deserve better than the "Nah, itll be fine" attitude that the SNP have been peddling for six years now.David Bone, Girvan.YET again Ruth Marrtrots out the untruth that The Vow was forgotten by those who committed to it, so once again, it is necessary to refute that assertion.The Vow of September  was signed by Prime Minister David Cameron, Deputy PM Nick Clegg and Leader of the Opposition, Ed Miliband and promised three things and three things only. These were: statutory protection for existence of the Scottish Parliament new extra powers for that Parliament and the preservation of the Barnett Formula. Of these, the first two were enacted in the Scotland Act  . The Barnett Formula also remains intact.Likewise, Ms Marrs claim that a No vote would guarantee EU membership is a distortion of the truth. What was in fact said was that a Yes vote would be a vote to leave the EU at the same time as Scotland left the UKndash which was based on the unambiguous opinion of the EU Commission as provided to the Scottish Parliament.Again the question must asked:Scottish independence is such a good thing, why do nationalists need to tell so many lies to convice the rest of us of their case Peter A Russell, Glasgow G.NICOLA Sturgeon in her daily briefing todaysaid that the Scottish Government has used the UK-wide Covid- testing system "which allows us to deliver economies of scale, so it is the right approach to take". Need I say more Ian Watson, Pitlochry.Read more: Letters: GERS figures show why we cannot leave the UK

title: letters-wrong-anthems-struggle
story: They celebrate violence, Mr Smith laments. There is not a country in Europe or any place  whose history has not been shaped by ldquoviolence conflict is endemic to the human condition. European literature opens with an epic poem of warfare, the Iliad. So does literature in the Lowland Scots tongue and John Barbour, author of The Brus, was a man with an exemplary record of service both as Archdeacon of Aberdeen and as a member of the royal council. Countries with records of resistance to domestic tyranny or foreign aggression generally take pride in those aspects of their history: does Mr Smith find something objectionable in that  Andsuch resistance leads to armed conflict, as it generally does, surely courageous and self-sacricing struggle against oppression is something to admire, and celebrate in verse and song  If Mr Smith disagrees, he is setting himself against most of the cultural history of the human race: a rather presumptuous standpoint.Perhaps it is a good job Mr Smith resides in Scotland. If the words of Flower of Scotland and Rule Britannia offend his sensitivities, what would he have to say of Le Marseillaise Derrick McClure, Aberdeen AB.MARK Smith is right about Rule Britannia and Flower of Scotland ndash the first is pompous and overweening, although with a jolly tune, the other an embarrassing dirge, foisted upon us by the rugby and football mob. He is wrong, though, to condemn any "anthemic" song which makes reference to battles and stre from the past. Although he does not claim that Flower of Scotland is our national anthem ndash which it certainly is not ndash he should be aware that many great anthems refer to the nations struggle ndash usually violent ndash to free itself from oppression, one of the greatest being La Marseillaise, of course. Some are very graphic and gory but no unpleasantness follows a passionate rendition, and as Mark Smith says, these things happened a very long time ago.When it comes to Scotlands national anthem ndash which somewhat scandalously we do not have ndash Scots Wha Hae is by far the most suitable. With words by Burns and a great tune, probably played at Bannockburn , admired by Bruch, Mendelssohn and others, when played "con brio", with a jaunty air, it is terric. The Scottish Parliament has many weighty matters on its plate for the foreseeable future, but it must address the matter of the National Anthem sooner rather than later.David Roche, Perth.NOTING that the BBC is to ditch the lyrics of Rule Britannia and Land of Hope and Glory, I suggest the organisation might choose something a little more humble and recommend the favourite of members of the Boys Brigade. I refer to Hymn  beginning "Will your anchor hold in the storms of le". It seems more apt.JW Frame, Bearsden.IF the BBC is serious about not causing offence at the proms maybe it should also stop playing Hail the Conquering Hero Comes, written by Handel to celebrate the Duke of Cumberlands "victory" at Culloden.Stuart Neville, Clydebank.

title: letters-prepared-testing-times
story: If, however, these hurdles are too daunting, the alternative is to take the day off and, with a tankful of petrol, drive to Carlisle ndash currently the nearest available test centre for my relativersquos Glasgow postcode.S MacKay, Glasgow G.DRESSING DOWNTHERE was always something for the Rag and Bone Man, who would appear about three times each year in the s, and his wee horse would be given a piece of bread and sugar . Then his horse became too old and he didnt come again but not to worry, as a shabbily-dressed lady with most of her top teeth missing, and with a strong Liverpool accent, arrived one day with a sob story about needing clothes for her poor grandchildren. She would appear each month and expect something. My mother complied, often giving her very nice things that she should have kept.Until, one day, my dear parent went to the large market in Liverpool to buy her next batch of baby chicks and there, with a little stall covered in nice clothes, was the "poor lady" selling things she had collected for her equally poor grandchildren, at very good prices. She was smartly dressed and also wearing a full top-set of teeth. My mother gave her the proverbial flea in her ear when she next appeared on our doorstep.Happy days.Thelma Edwards, Kelso.FOREST OF PLANKSDAVID Miller, in his responseto my letterabout a ldquoPlank of the Year suggests our nominations of politicians might dfer. He may well be right, but there is such a huge choice coming from all the parties that we are more than likely to agree about some candidates.Michael Watson, Glasgow G.TA FOR THE SNYSTERSI NOTE with interest your recent correspondence on Scots words .When I was a child one of the accepted rules at mealtimes was that you had to clean your plate before you could have a "snyster". So, you usually did not leave any food on your plate, as "snysters" were treats. In The Concise Scots Dictionary the meaning of the word is given as "sweets, cakes, dainties".If rarely you became "saucy" and turned up your nose at what was on offer, the threat was that you would get "whummely". I thought that that word was one of my fathers inventions, but in recent years, on consulting that same dictionary I found the word "whammle" or "whamlin" meaning "nothing to eat or drink". Words used in my childhood for food which still stir up feelings of comfort are clootie dumpling, saps, girdle scones, and a piece n jeely ndash not forgetting that confectionery delight, tablet.Amy Kinnaird, Ochiltree.I WAS most disappointed to learn that your compiler of Mondays Word Wheelhas not seen fit to include the words "yitter" and "yittering" in the solution. Like "cockabendie" , these guid Scotswords are still in use.William S Cooper, Strathaven.

title: biffy-clyro-buffoons-run-country-nurses-deserve-paid
story: That is the date of the Ayrshire trios special homecoming show at Glasgows Bellahouston Park. The gig is certain to be a sell-out, and the intriguing bill also includes Yungblud, Frank Carter and the Rattlesnakes, and Mercury Music Prize nominee Porridge Radio.The open-air showcomes as the new album, A Celebration of Endings, has just topped the UK charts, as well as attracting some of the best reviews of their long career.On one level, then, things are going exceptionally well for Simon Neil, James Johnston and Ben Johnston on another, however, there is still much for them to be angry about - about, for example,the "buffoons" in charge, about the treatment of nurses, about bands that play it safe.A Celebration Of Endings distils this anger into something bright and bombastic."We are living in a world right now in which politics cannot be ignored," drummer Ben Johnston said in an interview with Alex Green, the Press Associations entertainment reporter. "We are not historically a political band and we are not about to become Rage Against The Machine."He pauses for a rumbling laugh. "But I just think, right now, living in this world, you cannot ignore the buffoons in charge and all the crazy stuff that is going on."If you dont sing about it you are only lying to yourself because it is omnipresent."Ben was speaking just a week after he had reunited with his bandmates for their first rehearsal since lockdown.For the hard-touring outfit, the music industrys sudden grind to a halt was especially unsettling. "The first few weeks were all over the place - a lot of fear," the -year-old admits."My regime went entirely out the window and I started putting on a bit of weight and sleeping crazy hours and all sorts of stuff."But once the novelty of that wore off I got some more routine back in my le and things are fine now."Johnston, who had no formal music training, has spent lockdown going back to basics, practising on a drum pad and improving his technique.Lockdown has also affected the band in other, more unexpected, ways.Hailing from Kilmarnock, Bfy Clyro are famous for their eccentric style of power rock, performing topless at every opportunity, and for their love of Kilmarnock FC.Football was one of the immediate casualties of the pandemic, but, now it has ed, Johnston appears to have fallen out of love with the game."Im definitely missing the Killie," he says. "I really have missed the football, although weirdly since the English football came back - Scottish football hasnt come back yet - I realise I have slightly fallen out of love with football."I dont really know what happened. Im watching it, going This isnt as good as I remember and its really upsetting because I love my football."I think there are too many live games on a daily rate. I think thats just putting me off - Oh God, live football again."But no, I miss seeing my local team for sure. I miss going to my ground and shouting at guys in shorts."As you would expect, Johnston agrees that the arts need Government support and worries about how the pound. billion rescue package for the sector will be vied out.But hes equally concerned for the nurses, junior doctors and healthcare workers who have spent the last half-year on the front line of the pandemic."Im not one to get on my soapbox and start to worry about Government stuff," he admits. "There are more important things like nurses - they need to be taken care of. They need all the support in the world."They need to be paid twice as much, regardless of this pandemic."They need to be given free housing, they need to be given all the help, not turning up to food banks trying to feed their kids because they cant get a good enough wage as a nurse."That pisses me off. They are not given nearly enough support and this pandemic has shown that the people who are paid the least on the social structure are the people we need the most."We need to take a long, hard look at ourselves, think about that wealth gap and fix it."Despite their studio wizardry and penchant for aural experimentation, Bfy Clyro are at their heart a live band.If you have seen their energetic stage act you will understand that this period away must have been painful."Its been heartbreaking," says Johnston after a long sigh. "I completely forget what it is I do for a job. That happened so quickly, you wouldnt believe it."Even a couple of months, Im like Am I in Bfy Clyro  Did we play these shows  Its hard to even remember. I miss live music so much."The feeling you get from playing live cannot be replicated in any other manner. I miss it intensely."I was so happy to get back in the practice room just this week with the boys. Its the first time we have played since lockdown. Its such a release. Ive missed it heavily."He laughs at the suggestion that A Celebration Of Endings is Bfy Clyros most danceable album yet - but agrees."We have really broad tastes, We like almost every genre of music. We like making ourselves a bit unsure."You should always slightly question your music. It should always be on the edge of Is this brilliant or terrible  Im not sure but certainly not safe."The last thing we want to do is make safe music and call it in. I hate bands that do that."We always want to be on the precipice, looking over the edge."* A Celebration Of Endings is out now.

title: scottish-independence-new-panelbase-poll-business-scotland-puts-support-behind-yes
story: Some % of voters surveyed in a new Panelbase poll said a Yes vote would be good for the economy,representing a % lead in confidence in the independent economy of Scotland.The poll, for Business for Scotland, also found that% of Scots have more confidence in the Scottish Government to manage the economy compared with Westminster.The survey asked  Scotland-based voters: How much do you agree or disagree with the following statement  ldquoI have more confidence in the economic competence of the Scottish Government in Edinburgh than in the UK Government in Westminster.:SNP ministers drop annual economic case for independenceExcluding dont knows, % had more confidence in the Scottish Governments ability to run the economy and only % chose Boris Johnsons UK Government.% of voters also agreed that Brexit will be bad for Scotlandrsquos economy.The poll also found that almost a third of Tory voters rejected the notion that Boris Johnsonrsquos Brexit will be good for the economy.Business for Scotlands CEO Gordon MacIntyre-Kemp said: ldquo% would trust the Scottish Government to run Scotlandrsquos economy more than they trust Boris Johnsonrsquos government and that is reflected in the % support for independence found in the same poll.ldquoScotlandrsquos economy is run by Westminster and the Conservative Governmentrsquos Brexit omni-shambles with its comparatively poor performance in handling COVID-, including the threat to end the furlough scheme at the end of October regardless of the needs of business, is driving more and more people to believe in Scotlandrsquos ability to manage its own economy - I am tempted to ask how anyone could possibly think it couldnt :Nicola Sturgeon accused of elitism as clubs, pubs and music venues issue funding warningCommenting, SNP Depute Leader Keith Brown said: ldquoThis is a ringing endorsement of the SNPrsquos record in government, with voters choosing to put their trust in Nicola Sturgeon instead of Boris Johnson.ldquoItrsquos also more evidence,we needed it, that we are winning the argument over Scotlandrsquos future.ldquoThe SNPrsquos vision to create a flourishing economy, and fairer society, could not be further at odds with the Brexit chaos on offer at Westminster.ldquoWe will continue to work hard for the people of Scotland, and deliver whatrsquos best for the country as we look to recover from this pandemic.

title: douglas-ross-calls-nicola-sturgeon-adopt-trial-lockdown-self-isolation-payment
story: The UK Government has started a trial of the scheme in Blackburn with payments of up to pound for people who have tested positive for Covid- or been told they must isolate.The scheme is designed to protect people on low incomes who need to self-isolate and are unable to work from home. It is part of Englandrsquos track and trace services and will generate Barnett Consequentials for the Scottish Government.Mr Ross has called on the UK and Scottish Governments to work together to operate a trial in Scotland.He said: ldquoIn this new phase of local lockdowns, no part of the country should be left behind.ldquoWe must restore and rebuild our economy together, maximising the talents and skills of every worker and giving everyone the same opportunity to get ahead.He added: ldquoSo I am calling for a trial of this payment in Scotland. If it can be operated effectively, then it should be introduced for people in isolation who want to work but have no means of doing so, such as manual labourers, hairdressers and everyone  who canrsquot work from home.ldquoPeople across the country want to see both of Scotlandrsquos governments working together to protect them from the damage of this virus.
